alert.note: Alert for Hitchcock (Nebraska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Goodland (Northwestern Kansas and East Central Colorado)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 26 at 2:25PM CDT until May 27 at 5:03AM CDT by NWS Goodland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Nebraska... Driftwood Creek Near McCook 4sw affecting Red Willow County. Republican River At Mccook 1se affecting Red Willow County. Frenchman Creek Near Culbertson affecting Hitchcock County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Nebraska... Republican River At Stratton affecting Hitchcock County. .Heavy rainfall is causing multiple rivers and creeks to flow over their banks. For the Driftwood Creek...including McCook 4sw...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring. This approaches the flood of record. * WHERE...Republican River At Stratton. * WHEN...Until late tonight. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Lowland areas will become flooded. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:45 PM CDT Friday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:45 PM CDT Friday was 13.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 6.9 feet early Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.8 feet on 07/25/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 230 AM CDT.
